chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Discharging pilonidal sinus disease
chapter.summary: Covers the primary care management and referral of chronic discharging and recurrent pilonidal sinus disease.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 16 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage discharging pilonidal sinus disease?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If a person presents with discharging pilonidal sinus disease:
    • Refer to a colorectal or general surgical unit for surgical excision (urgency dependent on clinical judgement).
      • Surgical excision is the standard treatment for chronic pilonidal cyst and sinus disease. The surgery performed is generally one of two procedures: excision of infected tissue with primary closure (including various flap techniques) or excision with healing by secondary intention (including marsupialization).
      • The choice of technique depends on the characteristics of the pilonidal sinus, the experience and expertise of the surgeon, and the person's wishes. 
    • Offer paracetamol for pain and/or fever. 
      • If the response is insufficient, also offer a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), such as ibuprofen or naproxen (unless not tolerated or contraindicated).
      • See the CKS topics on Analgesia - mild-to-moderate pain and NSAIDs - prescribing issues for prescribing information.
    • Provide patient information on pilonidal sinus disease. For example:
      • Pilonidal sinus published by NHS (www.nhs.uk).
  • If the person has complex recurrent disease after definitive surgical treatment, refer to a colorectal surgeon with appropriate expertise and experience.
    • Surgical options for recurrent abscess or a small sinus include the 'pit picking' method, where the midline pit is removed, any superficial abscess scar is excised, and the track is cleaned out by a lateral drainage procedure.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based largely on The treatment of pilonidal disease: guidelines of the Italian Society of Colorectal Surgery (SICCR) [Segre, 2015], the German national guideline on the management of pilonidal disease [Iesalnieks, 2016], The American Society of Colon and Rectal Surgeons’ Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Management of Pilonidal Disease [Johnson, 2019], and on expert opinion in review articles on pilonidal sinus disease [Timmons, 2007; Marza, 2013; Gordon et al, 2014; BMJ, 2018; Kober, 2018; Choy, 2019].

Referral for surgical excision
  • The recommendation to offer referral for consideration of surgery for a person who has discharging pilonidal sinus disease is based on a number of guidelines [Segre, 2015; Iesalnieks, 2016; Johnson, 2019] and review articles on pilonidal sinus disease [Marza, 2013; BMJ, 2018; Kober, 2018; Choy, 2019].
    • In practice, it may be difficult to distinguish between chronic and recurrent pilonidal sinus disease in primary care, and specialist assessment can help to determine what, if any, surgical treatment may help.
    • The information on surgical excision is taken from The American Society of Colon and Rectal Surgeons’ Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Management of Pilonidal Disease [Johnson, 2019],
Offering analgesia
  • This recommendation is pragmatic and is based on what CKS considers to be good medical practice. In addition, expert opinion in two nursing review articles recommends offering analgesia to people with pilonidal sinus disease [Timmons, 2007; Marza, 2013].
Providing patient information
  • The recommendation to provide patient information on pilonidal sinus disease is based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
Referral for people with complex recurrent disease after definitive surgical treatment
  • The recommendation to refer a person with complex recurrent disease to a colorectal surgeon with appropriate expertise and interest is based on a review article of surgical outcomes for people with recurrent or persistent pilonidal sinus despite having had an elective definitive procedure. It concludes that careful selection of the operative strategy is needed for these people, rather than repeating previously failed procedures which cause further scarring and tissue loss [Gordon et al, 2014].
